text: The Chrysler by Chrysler is an automobile which was produced by Chrysler Australia from 1971 to 1976. It is an extended wheelbase, luxury variant of the Australian developed Chrysler Valiant. == CH Series== The original CH Series Chrysler was introduced in November 1971 replacing the Chrysler VIPChrysler by Chrysler CH Retrieved on 10 August 2010 as Chrysler’s competitor to the Ford Fairlane and the Statesman in the Australian prestige car market. It was offered in four-door Sedan and two-door Hardtop models. The Chrysler was based on the VH series Chrysler Valiant, utilizing the floorpan of the two-door Hardtop version. The wheelbase of the Chrysler was identical to that of the Valiant Hardtop and longer than that used on the Valiant Sedan. The Chrysler also differed significantly from the Valiant in external appearance, featuring a four headlight grille encircled by a chrome surround and a unique wrap-around horizontal tail-light assembly. The frontal styling was highly reminiscent of the 1971 US Dodge Coronet. A long list of standard luxury equipment items set the Chrysler further apart from the Valiant and included front disc brakes, power assisted steering, a push button radio with power antenna, a carpeted boot, tinted power operated windows and courtesy lighting which included adjustable reading lights for rear passengers. Considerable attention had also been taken to reduce Noise, vibration, and harshness (NVH) with the application of additional soundproofing material. Chrysler CH Sedan A Hemi six-cylinder engine was fitted as standard equipment, with an American designed, Australian built V8 available as an option. An imported “TorqueFlite” three-speed automatic transmission was used in all variants. Chrysler CH Hardtop == CJ Series== Chrysler (CJ) An updated CJ Series version of the Chrysler was released in May 1973,Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 129 one month after the VJ Series update of the Valiant.Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 113 This model of the Chrysler was distinguishable by minor cosmetic styling changes from its predecessor.Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 129-130 The four-door Sedan was now the only model offered, as the two-door Hardtop body-style was not carried over into this Series.Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 133 This model was also sold in some export markets, including Japan where it was marketed as the "Chrysler 318 CA" and featured a three-speed automatic transmission coupled to the smaller 5.2 liter V8 which was not offered in Australian market cars until 1976, with . Claimed top speed for the Japanese market model is . == CK Series== An updated CK Series version of the Chrysler was released in October 1975, coinciding with the release of the VK Valiant range.Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 135 & 145 Changes were again minor.Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 148 The V8 engine was modified to improve both economy and performance,Elizabeth Tuckey and Ewan Kennedy, Chrysler Valiant, 1996, page 147 however new emission regulations saw this unit replaced by a V8 from 1 July 1976.Valiant VK/CK Technical Specifications Retrieved on 10 August 2010 The CK Chrysler was discontinued in October 1976 with the introduction of the CL Series of Valiant and Regal models. This range included a luxury Chrysler Regal SE Sedan which effectively replaced the Chrysler,Tony Davis, Aussie Cars, 1987, page 147 although it did not feature the longer wheelbase or the unique styling features of the outgoing model. ==See also== * Chrysler Australia * Chrysler Valiant ==References== ==Further reading== * Joe Kenwright, 1971-73 CH Chrysler by Chrysler 360 Hardtop, Australian Muscle Car, Issue 42, pages 86 to 90 Category:Cars of Australia Category:Chrysler vehicles Category:1970s cars
